captions.text: Soldier, attention!

Sargent! 
What makes the green grass grow?

BLOOD, BLOOD, 
RED BRIGHT BLOOD!
What's the spirit of the warrior?
KILL, KILL, KILL WITHOUT MERCY!

What are the two types 
of people in this world?
THE QUICK AND THE DEAD!
What are you?
THE QUICK!
What are they?
THE DEAD!
Sargent, let me hear your war cry!
AAAAAAAAAH!

What you just saw 
was a small part of the training

I received while I was 
in the United States Army.
I joined just after September 11th.

They train you to harness 
a deep inner rage, a hidden rage.

A rage that most people 
don't even know they have.

In combat, 
that rage can keep you alive.

But at home, 
that rage can kill you.

Let me back up a second and
tell you why I joined the Army.

Most of you can probably remember
where you were on September 11th.

I will remember
for the rest of my life.

I was working as a forklift operator,
just out of high school.

I'm driving around 
and everyone disappeared.
I don't know where anybody is.

So I head up to 
the front of the building,

and everybody's 
around a small 13'' TV.

As I walk up, I watched the second plane
hit the Twin Towers.

I knew at that moment
that I was gonna join the military.

Before I made it to Iraq,
I spent about a year in Central America.
It was beautiful.

This is the upside to the Army.
You get to see the world.

I spent about a year 
bouncing around the jungles
of Panama, Nicaragua, Honduras.

I fell in love with the culture.
I got to see and try new things.

I even got to swim in the Atlantic 
and the Pacific in the same day
without getting on an airplane.
The good times didn't last, though.

In 2004, my unit received orders 
to deploy to the Middle East

in support of 
operation "Iraqi Freedom".

We were gonna be stationed
in Tikrit, Iraq.

It's Saddam Hussein's hometown,
right in the heart of the Sunni Triangle.

About halfway through my tour,
we received orders to go to Fallujah.

At the time, the insurgents controlled
the entire city of Fallujah,

and we were sent in 
to recapture the city.

I was the third gunner 
hanging at the top of a 50,

hanging out at the top 
of a humvee on a .50-cal.

And I was gonna be the eyes
and the ears of the convoy.

The drive from Tikrit to Fallujah
was only supposed to take about 10 hours
even with the slow military vehicles.
But the enemy had other plans.

On the way down, 
they started blowing up bridges
and setting up ambushes along the way.
We would redirect our path each time

we'd come into a new contact
and after 36 hours, with non-stop combat

no sleep and high stress,
your mind starts to play tricks on you.
I started seeing things that aren't there,
start hearing things that aren't there.
You start to lose control of your rage.

At some point, 
the second night with no sleep,

I must have fell asleep, dozed off,
the cool air rocking me to sleep,

'cause I woke to total chaos.
Gunfire.

I remember hearing the AK-47 rounds
hitting aside the humvee

just inches from my head:
"ting, ting, ting, ting".
I woke up, fear washed over me.
I remember the pink glow of our PG

shooting through the air
in every direction. Total chaos.

Explosions all around me. I lit up
the .50-cal: "thump, thump, thump",

"thump, thump, thump,
thump, thump, thump",
moving from one target to the next.

In the middle of all this chaos,
I could hear somebody laughing
and I thought to myself,

"who could be laughing 
at a time like this?"

And then I realized 
it was me laughing.

I felt like I was finally 
losing control of that rage
they taught me to harness.

Come time to leave Iraq,
and they asked for volunteers to stay.

They needed somebody to find
and neutralize the IEDs
that were killing so many people.

It wasn't a decision 
that I took lightly,

but if I didn't volunteer,
they were gonna pick people.

And I wasn't married, 
I didn't have kids,

and I didn't want them 
to pick somebody with a family,

so I volunteered
for a second tour.

That second tour, we spent 
3 or 4 vehicles to go out everyday.

We'd drive about 10 mph down the road,
barely moving.

We'd look at the side of the road,
trying to find the IEDs
Improvised Explosive Device,

and we'd wait for the road
to blow up on us.

While in Iraq, 
I lost 7 of my best friends.
Sargent, attention!
Right, face!
Present, halt!
Order, arms!
Left, face!
Forgive me.

My transition home was difficult,
to say the least.

I was paranoid, I carried
a pistol on me at all times.
I assessed the threat level

of every person or place 
I came in contact with.
Driving through my family's neighborhood,
I drove in the middle of the street,

and feared the side of the road
was gonna blow up and kill me.

On the outside, I looked like every other
21-year-old college student.

I bought the newest clothes, 
I played beer-pong,

chased girls,
rooted for the Buckeyes.

But inside, 
there was something wrong.

After a few months, my family 
and friends convinced me

that there's something wrong
and I needed some help,

I went to the VA,
walk-in mental health clinic,

and I told them, You guys gotta help me.
I'm gonna hurt someone.

I don't want to. I carry a pistol
to protect myself, but I'm scared.

They gave me a prescription for a
sleep aid, and sent me on my way

told me to come back in 6 months.
I didn't make it 6 months.

Few months later, 
I was down with some friends.

We were drinking, 
we're having a good time.

I'd been drinking every day
to deal with my issues.

It's hard to think of yourself 
as an alcoholic
when you're playing beer pong, but…

you're drinking everyday,
you're an alcoholic.

We're out, we're having some drinks
and an argument erupted over a girl.

Someone pulled out a knife, and I
snapped. I pulled out my pistol.

The prosecutor said I moved
through the room in a tactical manner

clearing the room, 
laid everybody on the ground.

I took the knife from him,
and I began beating him.
And I beat him, and I beat him.

A few days later I got arrested
for attempted murder

and several other charges.
Some I did, some I didn't do.

When I went in for sentencing, 
my judge told me,

Mr. Chambers, your service
is a double-edged sword.

Your time in Iraq makes you 
a threat to society,

and I have a civil obligation
to lock you up.

I received 10 years,
and here I am today.

Some of you that are familiar
with the TEDx format are probably
waiting on my call to action.
But you just did it.

Find a veteran and 
listen to his story.

A lot of us just need
somebody to talk to.
Sargent, attention!

Sarge, it's ok. 
You're home now, man.

It's over, you're safe. 
Welcome home.
At ease.
(Applause)

title: Your time in Iraq makes you a threat to society: Andrew Chambers at TEDxMarionCorrectionalSalon 2013

comments.text:
I think alcohol/drugs are more to blame than anything else here. The guy 
has some issues for sure thats goes back further than the military, he 
surrounded himself with shit bags also and that didn't help him. Its easy 
to blame the military and use it as our crutch for our violent behavior. I 
kept convincing myself of it but it just wasn't true. America is a war 
nation, a violent war driven society fueled by violent media and your 
childhood environment is the culprit and the military just fuels the flame. 
They are not helping him by encouraging him to act our his military 
traditions. He is still so caught up in that illusion, stuck in his 
military brain washing. It took a year or two for me to readjust to 
civilian life but i got over my brain washing and resumed a normal civilian 
life. I served in the Marine corp infantry from 2001-2005 and came home to 
a nice peaceful life of farming which helped a lot in my readjustment 
phase. The Marine Corps infantry didn't make me violent, angry, bitter, or 
hateful. I sowed my youthful stupid lust for blood and war in the corps and 
got out even more anti violence and anti war. I drank my fill of war and 
conflict, never again. Some guys just let it get to their head and take it 
too seriously, it takes much longer for these guys to readjust and some 
guys hold onto their military brain washing to a ripe old age. When you get 
out you're supposed to hang up your boots. When I got out I threw 
everything related to my military experiences in a box and try my best to 
never open it again. I even avoid talking about my military experience, ive 
even gone as far as not listing it on my job applications/resume. Ironic 
that im talking about it now though...traumatic experiences are best left 
locked up in the closet. Ive visited several psychiatrist/psychologists and 
one thing i learned is that a stranger can NEVER help you with lingering 
mental issues. As much as they pretend to care you are just another number 
to prescribe pills to. Thats when i found philosophy and it saved my 
life...for the time being.﻿

including the word "Esquire" in their title. 

Ben Franklin & company didn't do the U.S. any favors by agreeing to some

comments.text:
I see a lot of stupid in the comment section, and I just wanna say, if you 
think this sort of thing is 1. rational, or 2. needs to be punished, then 
there's about 35 textbooks dating back to Vietnam War that totally escaped 
your notice. Which is not a big surprise, considering that even DSM 
classified it wrong until 2013. As someone who is about to make a living by 
counseling veterans, I'll be more than happy to educate you, starting with 
brain development related to the age of the veteran, then continuing on to 
the actual neurological changes of those who have been in service depending 
on the length of their service, and ending with the inevitable and 
irreversible neurochemical damage that in most cases requires medication 
and extensive counseling. 
The days of 'shell shock' have long ended ladies and gentlemen, just in 
case you haven't noticed, science has moved past narrow minded judgment and 
it's definitely time for you to do the same. Vietnam war resulted in more 
than a third of its veterans committing suicide and more than 150K 
incarcerated. During World War II, those who suffered similar symptoms were 
dishonorably discharged and sent home with their names pinned to their 
shirts when they were too disoriented to communicate. Most of them died. 
It seems horrifying until you go through this video's comment section and 
see the evolution slide backwards in front of your eyes. These veterans 
live through more trauma then most people could even imagine. They don't 
need your judgment and they definitely don't need your excuses. It's not ok 
to beat someone to death, but it's equally not ok to refuse to acknowledge 
that there's something wrong here, something that VA is obviously not 
equipped to handle. Which is the real crime if you ask me. For a country 
with such a long history of misunderstanding and mistreating veterans who 
need help, that we are still failing them in 21st century. ﻿

comments.text:
I've spent four plus years between Iraq and Afghanistan.  I too shared my 
time in Fallujah in the same time frame he spoke of.  I was a combat medic 
then inside a infantry company (1-503 IN).  Given only a slice of my 
background, here is my view on this.  Chambers issue probably were formed 
earlier in life and were triggered by this experience.  He possessed a 
horrible coping mechanism and kept his emotions bottled; I think since he 
has learned to adjust, and so has the Army.  If you remove the emotion from 
yourself in these type situations, execute in which you are trained, and do 
your best to get yourself and brothers home; simply you have done your 
best.  We've done a great job with returning people home from a decade plus 
of two wars in which over a million people deployed.  We will continue to 
strive to bring that 90% survivability rate up to 95%+.  For all of the 
ones that will comment negatively I encourage you to display your lack of 
purpose, principals, and moral convictions out here.  As I know what I did 
and the good I provided to a purpose that was selfless.  Most cannot begin 
to understand my moral fibers, nor the price that I've seen paid. 
Others you can keep hugs and sad feelings for the experience I took on.  We 
are not weak nor ashamed of our accomplishments.  Give me and my brothers a 
chance to show you that we are better then most, and give us a chance to 
shine and formulate direction to accomplish goals.   We understand the risk 
when we sign and resign for more years.  We are not war junkies, and 
perhaps not all are cut from the same cloth.  That is your part to figure 
out, and assist where needed.﻿

comments.text:
This specific TEDx talk is particularly poignant to me. This specific 
message desperately needs to be seen by civilians so they know what they're 
dealing with when veterans return home from deployment. It took me quite a 
few years to integrate back to being what's considered "normal". I was 
disciplined frequently at work and even lost a job at one point because I 
reverted back to my training in a high stress situation. Civilians do not 
have a clue what we've gone through and what we're trained to do. It takes 
years to learn how to "turn off the switch." Even to this day, I have to 
stop and check myself to stop an over-reaction in an antagonistic 
situation. What the judge said to this veteran is highly insulting, and the 
10 year sentence he imposed was done out of ignorance. ﻿

comments.text:
13 months and 15 days, the last ones were the worst. One min i would kneel 
down and pray, the next id stand a curse. No place to run to where i did 
not feel that war, when i got home i stayed alone, and checked behind each 
door.

The ground at home was covered in snow, and i was covered in sweat. My 
younger brother calls me a killer... but my daddy calls me a Vet. Everyone 
says im someone else, and that im sick and theres no cure. Damned if i know 
who i am... theres only one place im sure.

Every summer, its all the same, i smell the cordite, i hear the planes. I 
cant tell no one, i feel ashamed, afraid some day ill go insane...

That was 10 long years ago and time has gone on by. But now and then i 
catch myself, eyes searching through the sky. All the sound of long ago 
will be forever in my head. Mingled with the wounded's cries and the 
silence of the dead.

*Salute*
Thank you for your service, thank you for your sacrifice. No matter the 
reason for your deployment or the objective of your mission, good or bad, 
you are our nations heros.﻿

comments.text:
I was perfectly employable as an automotive technician working for a Chevy 
dealer. Good potential for a decent middle class life given my 
circumstances. But I had an itch.... an itch, a curiosity to see what what 
was really going on in Iraq and Afghanistan. And i was tired of doing the 
same thing; day in and day out, as a cog in the machine, ants in an ant 
farm, 2 lost souls swimming in a fish bowl year after year..you get the 
point. The U.S. Army has educated me culturally, humbled me, and overall 
satisfied the need to travel and see the world. It has opened my 
perspective to how the world works as a whole. I am still actively serving, 
currently Germany as a SGT with 3 deployments. Unless you are rich and 
international in your job, you will always be limited from your primordial 
instinct to be a nomad and get out there and expand. This is why i continue 
to serve having reenlisted twice. As much bullshit as the military can be 
sometimes, Veterans can't deny the memories and experiences they had while 
in. Good or bad you're living life!
comments.author: iroc464

comments.text:
+SPArtan117ANDi Been there done that, got the T-Shirt.  And I'll tell you 
like I've told other aspiring 14-17 year olds I come in contact with.  If 
you go in, get a job that will translate well on the outside.  The military 
is a whole nother lifestyle.  You may not like it, or you may like it.  But 
either way chasing combat was a mistake I made at 17.  

When I got out my skills were, as Andrew Chambers stated, to drive 10mph 
down a road and hit IED's.  Route Clearance.  I too was a machine gunner. 
 I can craft a water impulse charge and blow open a metal door.  I'm an 
expert with many weapon platforms.  But I cannot hold a job if I find one. 
 Hell, it's hard for me to even buy a pack of cigarettes most days due to 
anxiety.  My hands shake in waiting rooms like Tom Hanks in Saving Private 
Ryan it's embarrassing.  

You do not come home the same from combat.  You will miss how easy it was 
to socialize in gatherings and even talk to your loved ones.  I got 
everything I wished for and then some.  When you lose friends the hatred 
intensify's.  And one day you might end up in a position where a difficult 
decision needs to be made with little hesitation.  It's not always clear. 
 There is a fog of war that plagues a battlefield.  

It's 5am and I haven't slept I'm on here searching for fellow brothers 
sharing their stories so I can take reference from them.  Take my advice. 
 Take care.

years later, it's never "over." We're trained a certain way, especially 
those of us who went infantry or some other combat MOS. Upon leaving the

Constitution/Bill of Rights in the name of enforcing any & all "laws", 
legal or not. Sorry, my oath was to uphold & defend the US Constitution,

returning the country back to the people, end of discussion as far as I'm 
concerned. Shit like what this judge said is common-place mentality with
